last_narrative:
Your decision to consolidate proves remarkably prescient. Over the following months, you focus your confederation's resources on strengthening what you've already built rather than pursuing grander schemes. The investment pays dividends beyond expectation—your territories' improved roads and harbors attract even more merchants, while your enhanced fortifications and trained militia make the region virtually impregnable to raiders. Most importantly, the careful development creates a stable foundation that other Norse leaders study and emulate, spreading your innovations organically across Scandinavia.

The consolidation effort reaches its peak during the harvest season, as delegations from across the Norse world gather to witness your confederation's prosperity. Your steading has become a showcase of what organized leadership and strategic thinking can achieve. Ragnhild, now pregnant with your second child, presides over feasts that host jarls, merchants, and scholars from Iceland to Kiev. Your three-year-old son plays among children who speak a dozen languages, growing up as a true citizen of the emerging medieval world.

But as you stand on your hall's carved gallery, watching ships from distant lands anchor in your harbor, the device on your wrist begins its familiar warm pulse. The sensation jolts through you like recognition of an old friend—or perhaps an old enemy. After nearly four years in this era, the time machine has found another random destination across the centuries. You glance at the small display: the date, the coordinates, the steady rhythm that means the window is opening once more.

Below you, your people prepare for the evening feast. Your pregnant wife discusses household matters with visiting noble ladies. Your son toddles between the legs of warriors who would die for him without question. The life you've built stretches around you in all directions—a confederation that bears your mark, innovations that will outlive you, a dynasty taking root in Viking soil.

[A] Press the device and let reality dissolve into whatever era calls beyond

[B] Oversee the evening's diplomatic feast—the window will remain open a little longer while you host the gathered Norse leaders

[C] Seek private counsel with Ragnhild about the strange dreams you've been having—the window will remain open a little longer for guidance

This is the player's FIRST era. They just used an experimental time machine in present-day Bay Area
to go back a few days, but the controls malfunctioned and threw them here instead.

They are disoriented, scared, and completely unprepared. Their modern clothes mark them as strange.
They have all the items listed in their INVENTORY - these items ALWAYS travel with them.

Begin the story in Viking Age Scandinavia (900, Scandinavia).

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Describe the MOMENT of arrival - disorientation, sensory details
2. Establish what the player sees, hears, smells immediately
3. Show the era's reality through details, not exposition
4. Create an immediate situation requiring response
5. Give the player character a name appropriate to how locals might interpret them
6. End with 3 choices

CHOICE DESIGN:
- All choices must be viable survival paths - no "give up" options
- At least ONE choice should reward understanding of THIS specific era
  (local customs, religion, social hierarchy, what outsiders could offer)
- The historically-informed choice should feel clever to someone who knows the era

TIME PACING: The arrival scene happens over the first few hours/day. Each subsequent turn 
will represent about 6-8 WEEKS (7 turns = 1 year). The travel window will stay closed for 
most of the first year, giving time to establish a life here.

- 2-3 paragraphs of arrival narrative
- Then present choices on their own lines:

[B] Second choice  
[C] Third choice

The world tears apart like wet fabric.

Your stomach lurches as reality reassembles around you—rough wooden planks beneath your knees, the acrid smoke of cooking fires stinging your eyes, voices speaking in a harsh, unfamiliar tongue. The Bay Area laboratory is gone. The sterile white walls, the hum of electronics, the coffee-stained workbench—all vanished. Instead, you kneel on muddy ground between long, low buildings with grass growing on their roofs. Your jeans and sneakers feel alien against your skin as people emerge from doorways, staring.

A massive man with braided beard and scarred arms approaches, his hand resting on an axe handle. He barks something at you—a question, maybe a command. Behind him, women peer from shadows while children whisper and point. Your phone weighs heavy in your pocket, the Swiss Army knife clipped inside your jacket. The ibuprofen bottle rattles softly as you shift. These people have never seen plastic, never seen synthetic fabrics, never seen anything like you.

The bearded man takes another step forward, his companions flanking him. Their eyes are sharp, calculating. You're clearly not from any neighboring settlement—your strange clothes, your soft hands, your clean appearance mark you as something unprecedented. They speak among themselves, and you catch the cadence of Old Norse from half-remembered linguistics courses. The big man points at you and says something that sounds like "Valdmarr"—maybe what they're calling you, or maybe someone they're fetching.

Their posture isn't immediately hostile, but it's wary. You need to respond before their curiosity turns dangerous.

[A] Try to communicate using gestures, showing you're peaceful and in need of help

[B] Offer them something from your pocket—perhaps the ibuprofen bottle as a mysterious gift

[C] Kneel formally and touch your forehead to the ground in the deepest submission you can manage

You drop to your knees and press your forehead to the muddy earth, arms spread wide in total submission. The gesture cuts through the tension like a blade—several warriors step back, muttering in surprise. The bearded leader, who you now realize must be the jarl, grunts approvingly. In this culture, such immediate and complete deference from a strange warrior-aged man speaks volumes about your respect for his authority.

"Valdmarr," the jarl rumbles, pointing at you. The name sticks—to them, you're now Valdmarr the Strange, who appeared from nowhere and knew enough to show proper respect. Over the following weeks, this first impression proves crucial. You're assigned to Thorkel, a grizzled thrall-master, but your immediate submission earned you a status above the other slaves. You're given a sleeping space in the main hall rather than the thrall quarters, and allowed to eat the scraps from the high table rather than gruel.

As autumn deepens into winter, you learn the rhythms of this place—Jarl Bjorn's settlement on a fjord that feeds into what you calculate must be the Oslofjord. The hall houses thirty souls: warriors, their families, craftsmen, and a dozen thralls. You've picked up enough Old Norse to understand basic commands and conversations. Your strange clothes have been supplemented with roughspun wool, though you've managed to keep your modern items hidden.

The jarl has taken notice of your quick learning and odd knowledge—you've impressed him by predicting weather patterns and knowing which stars to follow. But winter is deepening, and resources grow tight. Bjorn has begun eyeing his thralls with calculating hunger, and you've heard whispers of the midwinter sacrifice. Your position remains precarious.

When Ingrid the völva arrives for the midwinter blót, you approach her sacred grove with careful reverence. The ancient seeress studies you with milk-white eyes, her raven-feather cloak rustling in the bitter wind. You speak of dreams—visions of longships heavy with silver, of monasteries across the western sea, of a great king in a land of green hills who hoards gold in stone houses. You describe these "visions" in the cryptic, riddling speech the seeress prizes.

Ingrid's reaction exceeds all hopes. She seizes your hands with surprising strength, her blind eyes wide. "The ravens have shown you true sight, Valdmarr Strange-Dreamer," she whispers. "You speak of Ireland—the land of the Christ-slaves with their bell-towers full of treasure." Your careful descriptions, drawn from your phone's offline Wikipedia, align perfectly with recent rumors filtering back from early raiders. She declares you seiðr-touched—blessed with prophetic sight.

By the time the snows melt, your status has transformed entirely. Jarl Björn no longer sees you as a peculiar thrall but as his personal völva-blessed oracle. The real coup comes when your "vision" of ships arriving "when the ice breaks and the first plovers return" proves true—Irish monks fleeing Viking raids beach their vessel in the fjord exactly when you predicted, carrying silver chalices and illuminated manuscripts. Björn captures them effortlessly thanks to your forewarning.

Now, as spring raids beckon, you sit at Björn's right hand during feasts. The jarl speaks openly of the great westward expedition he's planning—thirty ships to strike the Irish coast. But Ingrid has begun asking pointed questions about your other visions, and you've caught her studying you when she thinks you're not looking. Your newfound prominence brings both opportunity and scrutiny.

The fleet departs with the spring tides—thirty longships cutting through slate-gray waters toward the Irish coast. You stand at Björn's shoulder aboard his lead vessel, wrapped in a cloak of wolf fur that marks your status as his seer. Your guidance proves sound: you direct them away from the heavily fortified monasteries near Dublin toward smaller, richer targets along the western shores. The raids unfold exactly as planned—swift strikes on isolated communities, churches heavy with silver, and minimal resistance.

At Clonmacnoise, your "vision" leads them to a hidden treasury that yields chests of Byzantine gold, and the warriors begin to whisper that Valdmarr Strange-Dreamer sees more truly than any völva. During the division of spoils, Hakon openly questions why a thrall—even a seiðr-blessed one—should receive a warrior's share. Several younger jarls nod agreement.

The damage compounds during the voyage home. Hakon spreads poison in every ear, claiming you attempted to bewitch him into betraying his jarl. To Astrid, whose husband's ship vanished in the storm, you promise to guide her brothers to the very monastery where her man's spirit cries for revenge. Your words are carefully chosen, mixing genuine sympathy with tantalizing hints of easy riches.

The response exceeds your wildest hopes. Not only do the bereaved families embrace your offer, but word spreads through the settlement of Valdmarr Strange-Dreamer's bold promise to lead a vengeance-raid. Other warriors, previously neutral, begin approaching you quietly. He rises immediately after you finish, his voice carrying across the Thing-mound. "Hear how the foreign thrall seeks to divide our strength!" he thunders. The visiting jarls murmur agreement—they've all heard the rumors of Harald's growing power, his demand that all Norway kneel or face destruction. Hakon presses his advantage: "What loyal man follows a thrall's visions when enemies gather at our very borders?"

Your supporters among the bereaved families cry out for vengeance, but the visiting jarls warn that dividing forces now invites Harald's conquest. The debate stretches through the day, growing heated as accusations fly. Your coalition of fifteen ships is cut to a third, while Hakon's faction celebrates this compromise as victory.
